The US has said, among other things, that the detainees at Guantanamo Bay are unlawful combatants and, as such, may be held for at least the duration of the hostilities.

(2) Yes, in relation to Mr Hicks. (Mr Habib was not a party to Rasul v. Bush, which was handed down by the United States District Court on 30 July 2002.) In her decision, Justice Kottar-Kotelly found that the Guantanamo Bay military base is outside the sovereign territory of the US and therefore the court did not have jurisdiction to hear the claims made by the petitioners - Mr Hicks and two United Kingdom citizens. Justice Kottar-Kotelly explained that her decision solely related to the jurisdictional issue and should not be read as stating that the petitioners do not have some form of rights under international law.

(a) Justice Kottar-Kotelly said that `the government recognizes that these aliens fall within the protections of certain provisions of international law and that diplomatic channels remain an ongoing and viable means to address the claims raised by these aliens'. Justice Kottar-Kotelly did not specify which provisions of international law she was referring to. Mr Hicks and Mr Habib are held in US military custody. Their treatment is therefore governed by US domestic law and international law as set out in international instruments to which the US is a party.

(b) As stated above in paragraph 2(a), Justice Kottar-Kotelly did not specify any rights under international law. The Australian Government has indicated to the US that, at this stage, while investigations are ongoing, we regard it as appropriate that Mr Habib and Mr Hicks remain in US military custody along with the other detainees. The Australian Government has an ongoing dialogue with the US and is cooperating with the US on a range of levels, including on the issue of law enforcement. Justice Kottar-Kotelly noted in her judgment that, `at least for Petitioner David Hicks in the Rasul case, diplomatic efforts by the Australian government have already commenced'. Australian authorities have been given access to Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, have made enquiries about the welfare and treatment of both men, and have contacted both families to advise them of the men's welfare. Australian officials who visited Mr Habib and Mr Hicks in May 2002 confirmed that both men are being detained in safe and humane conditions.

(3) In both cases, investigations are on-going. Australian authorities are working as quickly as they can to determine whether any offence has been committed against Australian law. The Government always expected that this process could take some time, given the number of complicating factors in these investigations, including complex legal and difficult evidentiary issues. The Government cannot comment further on the investigations due to the risk of prejudicing the investigations or the charges that may be laid. Neither the US nor Australia are currently in a position to commence a prosecution against either man.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 841 (Hansard, 25 September 2002, page 6990) concerning visits of Government representatives to Kurdistan, (a) who were the representatives, (b) when did they travel to Kurdistan and (c) what was the purpose of the visits.

(2) Has the Kurdish Government, non-government organisations (NGOs) or the media relayed to Australian authorities in Baghdad the decision to not remit 13% of total revenue from the oil for food program.

(3) Have the Kurdish Government, NGOs and the media repeatedly claimed that the United Nations Inter-Agency Humanitarian Programme will not provide them with specialised anti-cancer medicines to deal with the lasting affects of Iraqs Al-Anfal campaign in which 100 000 Kurds were gassed.
(4) Is the phrase three northern governorates of northern Iraq used in his answer the preferred description of Saddam Husseins Baathist regime for the Kurdish areas of Northern Iraq.
(5) Does the Government have a policy of not recognising the Kurdish authorities within the boundaries of a federal Iraq.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Mr Perry Head visited northern Iraq on 25 and 26 May 1993 when he was First Secretary with the Embassy in Ankara. The purpose of the visit was general familiarisation, as well as monitoring refugee and humanitarian issues, and the operation of Australian NGOs and other Australian personnel in the region.
(2) I am unaware of the decision referred to in this question.

(3) I am unaware of these specific claims, although I am aware of the report referred to in the reply to Question No. 841 (Hansard, 25 September 2002). I am also aware of a review conducted by the United Nations in January 2002 which noted that there had been an improvement in the availability of essential drugs and basic supplies in the three northern governorates in the previous two years.

(4) The term “three northern governorates” is the name most commonly used by the United Nations to refer to the governorates of Arbil, Dihouk and Suleimaniyeh. The term “three northern governorates” appears to be used rarely in official Iraqi Government statements.

(5) The Australian Government does not recognise any of the Kurdish “Parliaments”, “Governments” or “Congresses” - whether located in Iraq or elsewhere - and does not accord their representatives any special status.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Government aware of British geneticist Christine Godsens documentation of the extent and legacy of the Saddam Hussein regimes Al-Anfal campaign in which 100 000 Kurds were allegedly gassed by the Iraqi regime.
(2) Has the Australian Government examined Dr Godsens studies about the long term effects of Aflatoxin, gas and other chemical and biological weapons used against Kurdish civilians in Northern Iraq.
(3) Was the Al-Anfal campaign carried out mainly by killings through poison gas.
(4) How many Kurdish civilians does the Australian Government estimate were killed by round ups at night and mass executions in the Al Anfal campaign.

(5) Is he able to say what other effects were identified by Dr Godsens studies of the United Nations Special Commission Inspection team in relation to mutations and levels of sterility in Kurdish civilians during the Al-Anfal campaign.
(6) Is there evidence of wide spread liver damage amongst survivors.
(7) Is this the long term medical effect of the biological weapon Aflatoxin.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The work of Christine Godsens has been widely reported on the internet.
(2) The areas within my Ministerial portfolio have not examined Dr Godsens' report.

(3) Although precise details are impossible to confirm, public evidence, including the CIA report on Iraq WMD (published in October 2002), suggests that the majority of killings during the Al-Anfal campaign were carried out using conventional weapons.
(4) It is impossible to verify an exact figure for deaths in the Al Anfal campaign. Human Rights Watch estimates that between 50,000 and 100,000 were killed in the entire duration of the campaign.

(6) No reliable statistics are available on liver damage amongst Al Anfal survivors. Preliminary research indicates that there has been a rise in the incidence of diseases, mutations and cancers Iraq-wide, and not just in Kurdish areas.
(7) Liver damage is one of the possible medical effects from exposure to Aflatoxins.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the Government's position regarding the presence of Syrian troops in Lebanon.
(2) What is the Australian Government's position regarding UN resolution 520 which calls on all foreign troops to leave Lebanon.
(3) What effects does this presence have on the social and economic welfare of Lebanon.
(4) Does the Australian Government recognise the Taif Accord of October 1989, which calls for Syria's redeployment and the withdrawal from the country within a two-year period.
(5) Has the Australian Government called on Syria to withdraw in accordance with the Taif Accord.
(6) Has the Australian Embassy in Beirut ever raised abuses of Human Rights and Freedom of Speech in relation to the treatment of student protests.
(7) Has the Australian Embassy raised the recent closures of opposition station MTV and radio RML with the Lebanese Government.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Syrian troops are in Lebanon at the behest of the Lebanese Government. The Syrian presence is called for in the Ta'if Accord which ended the Lebanese civil war in 1990, and within the terms of the Treaty of Brotherhood, Cooperation and Coordination which has underpinned Lebanese-Syrian relations since the early 1990s.
(2) The Australian Government supports United Nations Security Council Resolution 520 and calls for its full implementation.

(3) The presence of Syrian troops in Lebanon has been a safeguard against the return to violence and civil unrest in Lebanon. They have assisted with the rehabilitation of important national institutions, such as the army and security services, and the building of the secure environment essential to permit the revival of Lebanon's economy. At the same time, some political and religious groups object to the continuing presence of Syrian troops in Lebanon. The Lebanese Government has begun a process of national dialogue to discuss these concerns.

(4) The Australian Government recognises the important role of the Ta'if Accord in ending Lebanon's civil war. It understands that the future of Syrian troops in Lebanon is a matter to be negotiated between the Lebanese and Syrian Governments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

quote.para: What is the Howard Government doing to encourage more high school students to undertake mathematics and science subjects in preparation for their final school examinations.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The teaching of science in our schools is of critical importance to Australia's future prosperity. It is vital that we, as a nation, continue to build on our scientific capabilities.

Regardless of whether students go on to scientific careers or not, a strong science foundation in the school years is important. Scientifically literate citizens are well equipped to understand change and apply innovative thinking and problem solving skills in their work and personal lives.

Due to the importance of science education, and to get an accurate picture of science education in schools, the Government commissioned a report on science education in Australia. The report, The Status and Quality of Teaching and Learning of Science in Australian Schools was released in March 2001. This report found that there are many excellent examples of science education in this country but noted a lack of consistency in quality.

The report showed that students who showed an interest in science throughout primary school often felt disappointed by the quality of science education available to them in high school. Lack of engagement, relevance and connection with their interests and experiences were the main reasons cited for this.

While it is important that students continue to study science and mathematics to the end of Year 12 and beyond, it is also important that the students who choose not to continue with these subjects gain a good understanding in the compulsory years. For many students, this is the only science or mathematics education they will take with them into their post-school lives. It is important that they gain an understanding they can utilise and build on.

In addition, school science and mathematics education also has to prepare students who may later pursue scientific or mathematical careers as well as provide all students with a good general education. By making science and mathematics more relevant for all students, these subjects will also be more interesting for those students who wish to pursue further studies or careers in these fields. If science or mathematics at school is interesting and relevant to students, it is reasonable to expect that more students will consider continuing their studies.

The Government has a wide range of initiatives in place to support secondary science teachers to make science more interesting and relevant. These are based on the assumption that excellent teachers are the key to exciting science. There are thousands of dedicated science teachers across the nation challenging the minds of students. These teachers need to be encouraged and supported to keep up with frequent change, new ideas on teaching and scientific discoveries.

Recognising the importance of science in schools, the Government has put in place three significant initiatives which are focussed on enhancing Australia's science and mathematics capability. The Higher Education Review has been undertaken throughout 2002 and will be considered in the context of the 2003 Budget. Australia's National Research Priorities were launched by the Prime Minister on 5 December. They are expected to provide a catalyst for the formation of teams and networks of researchers across many disciplines in Australia and internationally -- thereby stimulating further innovation and creativity. The Review of Teaching and Teacher Education is due to report in mid-2003 and is considering how to attract talented young people to teaching and how to develop a culture of innovation in schools.
In addition, this Government has a range of significant initiatives in place to secure Australia's future science and mathematics capability.
The Government's $3 billion Innovation Action Plan, Backing Australia's Ability has already done a lot to support the enabling sciences by:

- providing an additional 2,000 fully-funded undergraduate student places from 2002 for the priority areas of information and communications technology, mathematics and science. This would increase to nearly 5,500 places after four years as students continue in their programmes;
- providing $246 million over five years to upgrade systemic infrastructure in order to support world-class research and research training at Australian universities
- doubling funding for Australian Research Council Competitive Grants;
- establishing new Centres of Excellence in priority research areas;
- implementing the Science Lectureship Initiative.
. Other key Government initiatives include:
- the National Innovation Awareness Strategy that provides $35 million over 5 years principally to raise the awareness of science, innovation and technology;
- the Fostering Scientific, Mathematical and Technological Skills and Innovation in Government Schools ($143.5 million over four years);
- the $2.5 million National School Science Project that helps to improve the professional skills of, and teaching resources available to, primary and secondary science teachers;
- $240,000 for an investigation to identify the key factors that contribute to effective teaching and student learning outcomes in mathematics;
- the Quality Teacher Programme which is providing $159.2 million over six years to renew teacher skills and understanding in priority areas including science and mathematics;
- provision of close to $2 million for International Mathematics and Science Olympiads;
- supported the development of professional standards for mathematics and science teachers;
- provided $25,000 to support a National Numeracy Conference hosted by the Australian Association of Mathematics Teachers in Hobart on 4-5 October 2002;
- funding of $50,000 to support the 2003 National Youth Science Forum in Canberra;
- the new annual Prime Minister's Science Prize for science teachers; and
- the Government's $34 million contribution to the development of online curriculum, including science curriculum, through the Le@rning Federation.
